Does every connected set in $\mathbb{R}^n$ contain a connected subset which is not a point and not homeomorphic to the original set?

If $n\geq 2$ does every connected set in $\mathbb{R}^n$ contain more than $2^{\aleph_0}$ many connected subsets?



Asked by Erd\H{o}s in the 1940s, who thought the answer to both questions is yes. The answer to both is in fact no, as shown by Rudin \cite{Ru58} (conditional on the continuum hypothesis).




References


[Ru58] Rudin, M. E., A connected subset of the plane. Fund. Math. (1958), 15--24.
